Expectation1: Deliver packages on time and to the correct address
Situation1: A package arrives slightly later than expected, but still within the same day
Situation2: They strictly follow a detailed schedule of daily prayers, chanting, and offerings, ensuring nothing is skipped.
Story: I glanced at the clock on my phone as I pulled up to the depot. The package I was supposed to deliver had just arrived—later than I’d hoped, but still within today. My supervisor’s words echoed in my mind: “Customers expect their deliveries on time, no excuses.” I loaded the box into my van, feeling the familiar pressure to meet every deadline. But as I checked the address, my heart sank. If I left now, I’d miss my evening puja. Every day, I set aside this sacred time for prayers, chanting, and offerings. It’s not just a habit—it’s a promise I made to myself and to my faith, never to skip a ritual, no matter what. My family expects it, and so do I. Yet, the customer expects their package, and my job depends on it. I sat in the driver’s seat, torn between the ticking clock of my delivery route and the silent call of my altar at home. My hands trembled on the steering wheel as I weighed the demands of my work against the devotion that shapes my every day.
